title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: PRIMER PERMANOVA commonly used assess relative importance space, time, interactions multivariate community data. vignette demonstrates use two helper functions primertools compute AIC-like criterion PERMANOVA models: aic_permanova() — computes criterion summary quantities get_permanova_aic() — extracts quantities directly PRIMER PERMANOVA results table intent model comparison, hypothesis testing.

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: AIC-style score PERMANOVA models can computed : AIC=Nlog(SSres/N)+2ν \mathrm{AIC} = N \log(SS_{\text{res}}/N) + 2\nu : NN number observations SSresSS_{\mathrm{res}} residual sum squares ν\nu effective number fitted terms, computed asTotal df − Residual df Lower values indicate better-supported models, conditional response data distance measure.

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: package ships small example PERMANOVA output file:
code: f <- system.file("extdata", "PERMANOVA1.txt", package = "primertools")

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: first extract PERMANOVA table results. table must contain, minimum: Source column degrees freedom (df) sums squares (SS) rows labelled Total Res
code: tab <- read_permanova_results_table(f) tab Source df     SS      MS Pseudo-F P(perm) Unique perms 1         Lo  3  35564 11855.0   2.8086  0.0093          105 2     Si(Lo)  4  16883  4220.8   1.3564  0.0381         9849 3 Ar(Si(Lo))  8  24895  3111.8   1.2320  0.0076         9716 4        Res 64 161650  2525.7       NA      NA           NA 5      Total 79 238990      NA       NA      NA           NA

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: PRIMER outputs, number observations (N) typically Total df + 1. returned tibble contains: Model — object name (user-supplied label) SS_residual — residual sum squares nu — effective model complexity AIC — AIC-like score (rounded default)
code: N <- tab$df[tab$Source == "Total"] + 1  get_permanova_aic(tab, N = N) # A tibble: 1 × 4   Model SS_residual    nu   AIC   <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> 1 tab        161650    15  639.

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: already know relevant quantities, can call aic_permanova() directly:
code: SS_res <- tab$SS[tab$Source == "Res"] nu     <- tab$df[tab$Source == "Total"] - tab$df[tab$Source == "Res"]  aic_permanova(SS_res, N = N, v = nu) [1] 638.9

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: helpers designed used across multiple PERMANOVA models fitted data. practice, users typically: Fit several alternative PERMANOVA models PRIMER Export PERMANOVA table Read table R Combine results single comparison table structure work naturally purrr::map_dfr().

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: criterion intended relative model comparison, formal inference. Models must fitted response data using distance measure. Absolute AIC values meaningful—differences models.

title: Comparing PRIMER PERMANOVA models with an AIC-like criterion
text: vignette “Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs” details parsing PRIMER text files. ?aic_permanova ?get_permanova_aic

title: Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs
text: vignette demonstrates extract key results PRIMER PERMANOVA text output file using primertools. Specifically, show read: PERMANOVA table results estimates components variation

title: Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs
text: package ships small example PERMANOVA output file.
code: f <- system.file("extdata", "PERMANOVA1.txt", package = "primertools")  cat(readLines(f), sep = "\n") PERMANOVA Permutational MANOVA  Resemblance worksheet Name: Resem1 Data type: Similarity Selection: All Resemblance: S7 Jaccard  Sums of squares type: Type III (partial) Fixed effects sum to zero for mixed terms Permutation method: Permutation of residuals under a reduced model Number of permutations: 9999  Factors Name    Abbrev. Type    Levels Location    Lo  Random       4 Site    Si  Random       8 Area    Ar  Random      16  PERMANOVA table of results                                                 Unique Source  df          SS      MS  Pseudo-F    P(perm)  perms Lo   3       35564   11855    2.8086     0.0093    105 Si(Lo)   4       16883  4220.8    1.3564     0.0381   9849 Ar(Si(Lo))   8       24895  3111.8     1.232     0.0076   9716 Res 64  1.6165E+05  2525.7 Total   79  2.3899E+05  Details of the expected mean squares (EMS) for the model Source  EMS Lo  1*V(Res) + 5*V(Ar(Si(Lo))) + 10*V(Si(Lo)) + 20*V(Lo) Si(Lo)  1*V(Res) + 5*V(Ar(Si(Lo))) + 10*V(Si(Lo)) Ar(Si(Lo))  1*V(Res) + 5*V(Ar(Si(Lo))) Res 1*V(Res)  Construction of Pseudo-F ratio(s) from mean squares Source  Numerator   Denominator Num.df  Den.df Lo  1*Lo    1*Si(Lo)         3       4 Si(Lo)  1*Si(Lo)    1*Ar(Si(Lo))         4       8 Ar(Si(Lo))  1*Ar(Si(Lo))    1*Res        8      64  Estimates of components of variation Source  Estimate    Sq.root V(Lo)     381.69     19.537 V(Si(Lo))      110.9     10.531 V(Ar(Si(Lo)))     117.22     10.827 V(Res)    2525.7     50.257

title: Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs
code: tab <- read_permanova_results_table(f) tab Source df     SS      MS Pseudo-F P(perm) Unique perms 1         Lo  3  35564 11855.0   2.8086  0.0093          105 2     Si(Lo)  4  16883  4220.8   1.3564  0.0381         9849 3 Ar(Si(Lo))  8  24895  3111.8   1.2320  0.0076         9716 4        Res 64 161650  2525.7       NA      NA           NA 5      Total 79 238990      NA       NA      NA           NA

title: Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs
code: covs <- read_permanova_components_of_variation(f) covs Source Estimate Sq.root 1         V(Lo)   381.69  19.537 2     V(Si(Lo))   110.90  10.531 3 V(Ar(Si(Lo)))   117.22  10.827 4        V(Res)  2525.70  50.257

title: Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs
text: functions designed PRIMER v7–v8 text outputs. ignore auxiliary sections EMS tables pseudo-F constructions. word “Unique” added Unique perms column manually (“Unique” dropped reading table).

what: Writing a PRIMER-ready CSV with factors only
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: dat <- data.frame(   Sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3"),   Site   = c("A", "A", "B"),   Depth  = c(5, 10, 5),   SpA    = c(10, 0, 3),   SpB    = c(2, 5, NA_real_) ) dat Sample Site Depth SpA SpB 1     S1    A     5  10   2 2     S2    A    10   0   5 3     S3    B     5   3  NA tmpfile <- "forprimer.csv" write_primer_csv(   data = dat,   file = tmpfile,   sample_col = "Sample",   factors = c("Site", "Depth"),   variables = c("SpA", "SpB"),   na_to_zero = TRUE ) Wrote PRIMER-ready CSV: forprimer.csv cat(readLines(tmpfile), sep = "\n") ,SpA,SpB,,Site,Depth S1,10,2,,A,5 S2,0,5,,A,10 S3,3,0,,B,5 out <- read.csv(tmpfile, check.names = FALSE, as.is = TRUE) out SpA SpB    Site Depth 1 S1  10   2 NA    A     5 2 S2   0   5 NA    A    10 3 S3   3   0 NA    B     5

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: dat <- data.frame(   Sample = c("S1", "S2", "S3"),   Site   = c("A", "A", "B"),   Depth  = c(5, 10, 5),   SpA    = c(10, 0, 3),   SpB    = c(2, 5, NA_real_) )

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: dat Sample Site Depth SpA SpB 1     S1    A     5  10   2 2     S2    A    10   0   5 3     S3    B     5   3  NA

what: Create a temporary file to write the CSV to
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: tmpfile <- "forprimer.csv"

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: write_primer_csv(   data = dat,   file = tmpfile,   sample_col = "Sample",   factors = c("Site", "Depth"),   variables = c("SpA", "SpB"),   na_to_zero = TRUE ) Wrote PRIMER-ready CSV: forprimer.csv

what: Display the contents of the written CSV file
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: cat(readLines(tmpfile), sep = "\n") ,SpA,SpB,,Site,Depth S1,10,2,,A,5 S2,0,5,,A,10 S3,3,0,,B,5

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: out <- read.csv(tmpfile, check.names = FALSE, as.is = TRUE) out SpA SpB    Site Depth 1 S1  10   2 NA    A     5 2 S2   0   5 NA    A    10 3 S3   3   0 NA    B     5

what: Writing a PRIMER-ready CSV with factors and indicators
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: inds <- data.frame(   variable = c("SpA", "SpB"),   Trophic  = c("Carnivore", "Omnivore"),   Guild    = c("Reef", "Reef") ) inds variable   Trophic Guild 1      SpA Carnivore  Reef 2      SpB  Omnivore  Reef tmpfile <- "forprimer_ind.csv" write_primer_csv(   data = dat,   file = tmpfile,   sample_col = "Sample",   factors = c("Site", "Depth"),   variables = c("SpA", "SpB"),   na_to_zero = TRUE,   indicators = inds,   indicators_var_col = "variable" ) Wrote PRIMER-ready CSV: forprimer_ind.csv cat(readLines(tmpfile), sep = "\n") ,SpA,SpB,,Site,Depth S1,10,2,,A,5 S2,0,5,,A,10 S3,3,0,,B,5 ,,,,, Trophic,Carnivore,Omnivore,,, Guild,Reef,Reef,,, out <- read.csv(tmpfile, check.names = FALSE, as.is = TRUE) out SpA      SpB    Site Depth 1      S1        10        2 NA    A     5 2      S2         0        5 NA    A    10 3      S3         3        0 NA    B     5 4                            NA         NA 5 Trophic Carnivore Omnivore NA         NA 6   Guild      Reef     Reef NA         NA

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: inds <- data.frame(   variable = c("SpA", "SpB"),   Trophic  = c("Carnivore", "Omnivore"),   Guild    = c("Reef", "Reef") )

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: inds variable   Trophic Guild 1      SpA Carnivore  Reef 2      SpB  Omnivore  Reef

what: Create a temporary file to write the CSV to
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: tmpfile <- "forprimer_ind.csv"

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: write_primer_csv(   data = dat,   file = tmpfile,   sample_col = "Sample",   factors = c("Site", "Depth"),   variables = c("SpA", "SpB"),   na_to_zero = TRUE,   indicators = inds,   indicators_var_col = "variable" ) Wrote PRIMER-ready CSV: forprimer_ind.csv

what: Display the contents of the written CSV file
title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: cat(readLines(tmpfile), sep = "\n") ,SpA,SpB,,Site,Depth S1,10,2,,A,5 S2,0,5,,A,10 S3,3,0,,B,5 ,,,,, Trophic,Carnivore,Omnivore,,, Guild,Reef,Reef,,,

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
code: out <- read.csv(tmpfile, check.names = FALSE, as.is = TRUE) out SpA      SpB    Site Depth 1      S1        10        2 NA    A     5 2      S2         0        5 NA    A    10 3      S3         3        0 NA    B     5 4                            NA         NA 5 Trophic Carnivore Omnivore NA         NA 6   Guild      Reef     Reef NA         NA

title: Creating a PRIMER-ready CSV
text: na_to_zero = TRUE replaces missing values 0. output blank first column header blank separator column. Indicators added , aligned variable columns.

title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: vignette shows read PRIMER SIMPER text output file structured list within-group -group contribution tables. also demonstrates helper functions convert nested list output tidy tibbles easier filter, join, tabulate, plot.

what: Read an example file shipped with the package
title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
code: simper_path <- system.file("extdata", "SIMPER1.txt", package = "primertools") simper_path [1] "/home/runner/work/_temp/Library/primertools/extdata/SIMPER1.txt" x <- read_simper(simper_path)  names(x) [1] "metadata" "within"   "between" names(x$within) [1] "B" "A" "H" "L" names(x$between) [1] "B vs A" "B vs H" "A vs H" "B vs L" "A vs L" "H vs L"

title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: within element named list data frames, one per group.
code: x$within$A species av_abund av_sim sim_sd contrib   cum group 1        Hiatella arctica    16.70  12.75   1.34   33.80 33.80     A 2       Chlamys zelandiae     8.80   6.43   1.18   17.04 50.84     A 3      Lamellaria ophione     3.85   3.40   0.82    9.01 59.85     A 4         Xymene pusillus     4.35   3.22   1.36    8.54 68.38     A 5 Trichomusculus barbatus     2.65   1.97   0.97    5.21 73.60     A   avg_similarity 1          37.72 2          37.72 3          37.72 4          37.72 5          37.72

what: Helper: convert within-group results to a single tibble
title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: tidy_simper_within() stacks within-group tables one tibble adds group column. makes easy filter cumulative contribution work results using standard tidyverse workflows. Example: show top 10 taxa per group contribution.
code: d_within <- tidy_simper_within(x, cum_max = 90)  d_within # A tibble: 18 × 8    taxon               av_abund av_sim sim_sd contrib   cum group avg_similarity    <chr>                  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>  1 Trichomusculus bar…     5.05   6.33   1      21.8   21.8 B               29.1  2 Hiatella arctica        3.7    4.59   1.31   15.8   37.5 B               29.1  3 Eatoniella roseoci…     5.35   3.32   0.7    11.4   48.9 B               29.1  4 Pisinna olivacea i…     3.65   2.5    0.74    8.61  57.5 B               29.1  5 Borniola reniformis     5.2    2.2    0.53    7.55  65.1 B               29.1  6 Eatoniella albocol…     2      2.12   0.67    7.29  72.4 B               29.1  7 Hiatella arctica       16.7   12.8    1.34   33.8   33.8 A               37.7  8 Chlamys zelandiae       8.8    6.43   1.18   17.0   50.8 A               37.7  9 Lamellaria ophione      3.85   3.4    0.82    9.01  59.8 A               37.7 10 Xymene pusillus         4.35   3.22   1.36    8.54  68.4 A               37.7 11 Trichomusculus bar…     2.65   1.97   0.97    5.21  73.6 A               37.7 12 Hiatella arctica       13.2   11.0    1.52   32.4   32.4 H               34.2 13 Chlamys zelandiae       7.75   5.67   1.55   16.6   49.0 H               34.2 14 Trichomusculus bar…     6.25   4.65   1.59   13.6   62.6 H               34.2 15 Cantharidus purpur…     2.85   1.94   0.89    5.68  68.2 H               34.2 16 Borniola reniformis     3.7    1.73   0.81    5.08  73.3 H               34.2 17 Hiatella arctica       12.3   17.3    1.44   48.1   48.1 L               35.9 18 Trichomusculus bar…     5.1    8.76   1.25   24.4   72.5 L               35.9 d_within |>   dplyr::group_by(group) |>   dplyr::slice_max(contrib, n = 10, with_ties = FALSE) |>   dplyr::ungroup() # A tibble: 18 × 8    taxon               av_abund av_sim sim_sd contrib   cum group avg_similarity    <chr>                  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>  1 Hiatella arctica       16.7   12.8    1.34   33.8   33.8 A               37.7  2 Chlamys zelandiae       8.8    6.43   1.18   17.0   50.8 A               37.7  3 Lamellaria ophione      3.85   3.4    0.82    9.01  59.8 A               37.7  4 Xymene pusillus         4.35   3.22   1.36    8.54  68.4 A               37.7  5 Trichomusculus bar…     2.65   1.97   0.97    5.21  73.6 A               37.7  6 Trichomusculus bar…     5.05   6.33   1      21.8   21.8 B               29.1  7 Hiatella arctica        3.7    4.59   1.31   15.8   37.5 B               29.1  8 Eatoniella roseoci…     5.35   3.32   0.7    11.4   48.9 B               29.1  9 Pisinna olivacea i…     3.65   2.5    0.74    8.61  57.5 B               29.1 10 Borniola reniformis     5.2    2.2    0.53    7.55  65.1 B               29.1 11 Eatoniella albocol…     2      2.12   0.67    7.29  72.4 B               29.1 12 Hiatella arctica       13.2   11.0    1.52   32.4   32.4 H               34.2 13 Chlamys zelandiae       7.75   5.67   1.55   16.6   49.0 H               34.2 14 Trichomusculus bar…     6.25   4.65   1.59   13.6   62.6 H               34.2 15 Cantharidus purpur…     2.85   1.94   0.89    5.68  68.2 H               34.2 16 Borniola reniformis     3.7    1.73   0.81    5.08  73.3 H               34.2 17 Hiatella arctica       12.3   17.3    1.44   48.1   48.1 L               35.9 18 Trichomusculus bar…     5.1    8.76   1.25   24.4   72.5 L               35.9

what: Helper: convert between-group results to a single tibble
title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: tidy_simper_between() stacks -group tables one tibble adds contrast column. also computes delta_abund = av_abund_1 - av_abund_2 indicate group higher average abundance taxon. Example: extract top contributors one contrast.
code: d_between <- tidy_simper_between(x, cum_max = 70)  d_between # A tibble: 89 × 12    taxon       av_abund_1 av_abund_2 av_diss diss_sd contrib   cum group1 group2    <chr>            <dbl>      <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>  1 Hiatella a…       3.7       16.7    12.6     1.14   16.1   16.1 B      A  2 Chlamys ze…       0.85       8.8     7.46    1.03    9.57  25.7 B      A  3 Borniola r…       5.2        3       4.62    0.95    5.92  31.6 B      A  4 Eatoniella…       5.35       1.45    4.47    0.88    5.73  37.3 B      A  5 Trichomusc…       5.05       2.65    4.11    0.9     5.28  42.6 B      A  6 Lamellaria…       0.45       3.85    4.1     0.85    5.26  47.9 B      A  7 Xymene pus…       0.6        4.35    3.48    1.13    4.46  52.3 B      A  8 Pisinna ol…       3.65       2.4     3.36    1.02    4.32  56.6 B      A  9 Crepidula …       2.15       2.25    2.54    1.13    3.26  59.9 B      A 10 Eatoniella…       2          0.15    2.02    0.87    2.6   62.5 B      A # ℹ 79 more rows # ℹ 3 more variables: avg_dissimilarity <dbl>, contrast <chr>, #   delta_abund <dbl> d_between |>   dplyr::filter(contrast == "A vs H") |>   dplyr::arrange(desc(contrib)) |>   dplyr::slice_head(n = 15) # A tibble: 15 × 12    taxon       av_abund_1 av_abund_2 av_diss diss_sd contrib   cum group1 group2    <chr>            <dbl>      <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr>  1 Hiatella a…      16.7       13.2    10.2     1.07   14.8   14.8 A      H  2 Chlamys ze…       8.8        7.75    6.11    1.05    8.86  23.6 A      H  3 Trichomusc…       2.65       6.25    3.29    1.18    4.77  28.4 A      H  4 Lamellaria…       3.85       0.8     3.27    0.77    4.75  33.1 A      H  5 Xymene pus…       4.35       1.5     3.18    1.12    4.62  37.8 A      H  6 Pisinna ol…       2.4        4.25    3.06    0.98    4.44  42.2 A      H  7 Borniola r…       3          3.7     2.91    1.1     4.22  46.4 A      H  8 Eatonina m…       0.85       3.2     2.18    0.8     3.16  49.6 A      H  9 Cantharidu…       0.3        2.85    1.99    1.12    2.88  52.5 A      H 10 Eatoniella…       1.45       2.05    1.86    0.75    2.7   55.2 A      H 11 Crepidula …       2.25       0.1     1.8     0.94    2.62  57.8 A      H 12 Curveulima…       1.95       0.6     1.67    0.66    2.42  60.2 A      H 13 Onithochit…       2          1.55    1.6     0.96    2.32  62.5 A      H 14 Fictonoba …       0.65       1.8     1.46    0.57    2.11  64.6 A      H 15 Asteracmea…       1.9        0.15    1.4     0.82    2.03  66.7 A      H # ℹ 3 more variables: avg_dissimilarity <dbl>, contrast <chr>, #   delta_abund <dbl>

what: Helper: make within-facet ordering for plots
title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: plotting SIMPER contributions faceted panels (e.g., one panel per group), ggplot2 orders factor levels globally. add_taxon_group_order() adds plotting-factor (taxon_group) ordered within group.
code: d_within_plot <- d_within |>   add_taxon_group_order()  d_within_plot |>   dplyr::select(taxon, group, contrib, taxon_group) |>   dplyr::slice_head(n = 10) # A tibble: 10 × 4    taxon                     group contrib taxon_group    <chr>                     <chr>   <dbl> <fct>  1 Trichomusculus barbatus   B       21.8  Trichomusculus barbatus___B  2 Hiatella arctica          B       15.8  Hiatella arctica___B  3 Eatoniella roseocincta    B       11.4  Eatoniella roseocincta___B  4 Pisinna olivacea impressa B        8.61 Pisinna olivacea impressa___B  5 Borniola reniformis       B        7.55 Borniola reniformis___B  6 Eatoniella albocolumella  B        7.29 Eatoniella albocolumella___B  7 Hiatella arctica          A       33.8  Hiatella arctica___A  8 Chlamys zelandiae         A       17.0  Chlamys zelandiae___A  9 Lamellaria ophione        A        9.01 Lamellaria ophione___A 10 Xymene pusillus           A        8.54 Xymene pusillus___A library(ggplot2)  ggplot(d_within_plot, aes(x = contrib, y = taxon_group)) +   geom_col() +   facet_wrap(~ group, scales = "free_y") +   tidytext::scale_y_reordered() +   labs(     title = "Within-group SIMPER",     subtitle = "Taxa contributing to within-group Bray–Curtis similarity (cumulative cutoff applied)",     x = "Contribution to within-group similarity (%)",     y = NULL   )

title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(d_within_plot, aes(x = contrib, y = taxon_group)) +   geom_col() +   facet_wrap(~ group, scales = "free_y") +   tidytext::scale_y_reordered() +   labs(     title = "Within-group SIMPER",     subtitle = "Taxa contributing to within-group Bray–Curtis similarity (cumulative cutoff applied)",     x = "Contribution to within-group similarity (%)",     y = NULL   )

title: Reading PRIMER SIMPER outputs
text: SIMPER descriptive decomposition average similarity/dissimilarity taxon contributions. Contributions independent SIMPER provide measures statistical uncertainty.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Adam N. H. Smith. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Smith (2026). primertools: Tools Reading Writing PRIMER Files. R package version 0.2.0, https://anhsmith.github.io/primertools/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {primertools: Tools for Reading and Writing PRIMER Files},   author = {Adam N. H. Smith},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://anhsmith.github.io/primertools/}, }

what: Tools for Reading and Writing PRIMER Files
title: Tools for Reading and Writing PRIMER Files
text: primertools package provides helper functions preparing datasets import intoPRIMER-e software, reading common PRIMER output files (e.g. PERMANOVA results) downstream analysis R. primertools designed support reproducible workflows combine PRIMER R. reimplement PRIMER analyses.

title: Tools for Reading and Writing PRIMER Files
text: PRIMER widely used software package (made PRIMER-e) multivariate analysis ecological community data. Although R provides packages overlapping functionality, PRIMER software authoritative implementation routines provides. PRIMER-e website PRIMER-e learning hub use PRIMER R?

title: Tools for Reading and Writing PRIMER Files
text: can install development version primertools GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("anhsmith/primertools") library(primertools)

what: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
title: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
text: ggplot2 orders factors globally, faceted SIMPER plots need plotting-factor ordered within group. function adds taxon_group.

title: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
code: add_taxon_group_order(   d_within,   group_var = "group",   taxon_var = "taxon",   order_var = "contrib",   decreasing = TRUE )

title: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
text: d_within tibble tidy_simper_within(). group_var Column name giving facet/group (default group). taxon_var Column name giving taxon label (default taxon). order_var Column used order taxa within group (default contrib). decreasing TRUE (default), order largest smallest.

title: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
text: tibble additional factor column taxon_group.

title: Add a within-facet ordering variable for SIMPER plots — add_taxon_group_order
code: # d_within <- tidy_simper_within(simper_site_cp) # d_within <- add_taxon_group_order(d_within)

what: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova
title: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova
text: Computes AIC-style criterion using residual sum--squares, sample size, number fitted terms/parameters (v).

title: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova
code: aic_permanova(SS_res, N, v, round_n = 1)

title: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova
text: SS_res Residual sum--squares (numeric scalar). N Number observations (numeric/integer scalar). v Model complexity term (numeric/integer scalar). round_n Round .

title: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova
text: numeric scalar rounded round_n decimal place.

title: AIC-like criterion for PERMANOVA models — aic_permanova

what: Extract PERMANOVA AIC components from a PRIMER PERMANOVA table — get_permanova_aic
title: Extract PERMANOVA AIC components from a PRIMER PERMANOVA table — get_permanova_aic
text: Convenience wrapper pull residual SS \(\nu\) (nu) PRIMER PERMANOVA table (columns including Source, SS, df), compute AIC-like score.

title: Extract PERMANOVA AIC components from a PRIMER PERMANOVA table — get_permanova_aic
code: get_permanova_aic(x, model_name = NULL, N)

title: Extract PERMANOVA AIC components from a PRIMER PERMANOVA table — get_permanova_aic
text: x data frame/tibble Source column least SS df. Must contain rows named Res Total Source. model_name Optional model label. NULL, uses name x. N Number observations (Total df + 1 PRIMER contexts).

title: Extract PERMANOVA AIC components from a PRIMER PERMANOVA table — get_permanova_aic
text: tibble columns Model, SS_residual, nu, AIC.

what: primertools: Utilities for reading and writing PRIMER files — primertools
title: primertools: Utilities for reading and writing PRIMER files — primertools
text: Helper functions writing PRIMER import files reading PRIMER export files.

title: primertools: Utilities for reading and writing PRIMER files — primertools
text: Maintainer: Adam N. H. Smith anhsmith@gmail.com

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: Parses Estimates components variation section PRIMER PERMANOVA text output file data frame.

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
code: read_permanova_components_of_variation(path, encoding = "UTF-8")

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: path Path PRIMER PERMANOVA text output file. encoding File encoding passed readLines(). Default "UTF-8".

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: data frame containing estimates components variation.

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ covs <- read_permanova_components_of_variation("PM_SiteCycle.txt") covs } # }

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: Parses PERMANOVA table results section PRIMER PERMANOVA text output file data frame.

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
code: read_permanova_results_table(path, encoding = "UTF-8")

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: path Path PRIMER PERMANOVA text output file. encoding File encoding passed readLines(). Default "UTF-8".

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: data frame containing PERMANOVA results table.

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
text: PRIMER prints label permutations column across two lines (.e., Unique one line perms next) can sometimes misaligned plain-text exports. function ignores line just Unique simply renames perms column Unique perms later clarity.

title: Read PRIMER PERMANOVA
code: f <- system.file("extdata", "PERMANOVA1.txt", package = "primertools") if (file.exists(f)) {   tab  <- read_permanova_results_table(f)   covs <- read_permanova_components_of_variation(f) }

what: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
text: Parses PRIMER SIMPER output : metadata Named list header fields found file. within Named list data.frames, one per group (within-group similarities). Named list data.frames, one per pair (-group dissimilarities).

title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
code: read_simper(path)

title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
text: path Path PRIMER SIMPER text output file.

title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
text: named list elements metadata, within, .

title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
text: reader targets one-way SIMPER layout within-group blocks start lines like "Group " -group blocks start lines like "Groups & B".

title: Read a PRIMER SIMPER text output file (one-way) — read_simper
code: f <- system.file("extdata", "SIMPER1.txt", package = "primertools") x <- read_simper(f) names(x$within) #> [1] "B" "A" "H" "L" names(x$between) #> [1] "B vs A" "B vs H" "A vs H" "B vs L" "A vs L" "H vs L" head(x$within[[1]]) #>                     species av_abund av_sim sim_sd contrib   cum group #> 1   Trichomusculus barbatus     5.05   6.33   1.00   21.75 21.75     B #> 2          Hiatella arctica     3.70   4.59   1.31   15.76 37.51     B #> 3    Eatoniella roseocincta     5.35   3.32   0.70   11.42 48.93     B #> 4 Pisinna olivacea impressa     3.65   2.50   0.74    8.61 57.53     B #> 5       Borniola reniformis     5.20   2.20   0.53    7.55 65.08     B #> 6  Eatoniella albocolumella     2.00   2.12   0.67    7.29 72.38     B #>   avg_similarity #> 1           29.1 #> 2           29.1 #> 3           29.1 #> 4           29.1 #> 5           29.1 #> 6           29.1 head(x$between[[1]]) #>                   species av_abund_1 av_abund_2 av_diss diss_sd contrib   cum #> 1        Hiatella arctica       3.70      16.70   12.55    1.14   16.11 16.11 #> 2       Chlamys zelandiae       0.85       8.80    7.46    1.03    9.57 25.68 #> 3     Borniola reniformis       5.20       3.00    4.62    0.95    5.92 31.60 #> 4  Eatoniella roseocincta       5.35       1.45    4.47    0.88    5.73 37.34 #> 5 Trichomusculus barbatus       5.05       2.65    4.11    0.90    5.28 42.61 #> 6      Lamellaria ophione       0.45       3.85    4.10    0.85    5.26 47.87 #>   group1 group2 avg_dissimilarity #> 1      B      A             77.93 #> 2      B      A             77.93 #> 3      B      A             77.93 #> 4      B      A             77.93 #> 5      B      A             77.93 #> 6      B      A             77.93

what: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
title: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
text: Convert primertools SIMPER object single tibble -group results, optionally truncating cumulative contribution.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
code: tidy_simper_between(simper_obj, cum_max = 70)

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
text: simper_obj SIMPER object produced primertools (must contain $). cum_max Cumulative cutoff (percent). Keep rows cum <= cum_max.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
text: tibble one row per taxon per contrast.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (between-group tables) — tidy_simper_between
code: # d_between <- tidy_simper_between(simper_site_cp, cum_max = 60)

what: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
title: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
text: Convert primertools SIMPER object single tibble within-group results, optionally truncating cumulative contribution.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
code: tidy_simper_within(simper_obj, cum_max = 70)

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
text: simper_obj SIMPER object produced primertools (must contain $within). cum_max Cumulative cutoff (percent). Keep rows cum <= cum_max.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
text: tibble one row per taxon per group.

title: Tidy a SIMPER object (within-group tables) — tidy_simper_within
code: # d_within <- tidy_simper_within(simper_site_cp, cum_max = 70)

what: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
title: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
text: Layout: First column: sample names (blank header) Variable columns (numeric) Blank separator column (blank header) Factor columns (sample metadata) Optional: blank row, one row per Indicator (variable metadata)

title: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
code: write_primer_csv(   data,   file,   sample_col,   factors = NULL,   variables = NULL,   na_to_zero = FALSE,   indicators = NULL,   indicators_var_col = "variable" )

title: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
text: data Data frame least sample ID column variable columns. file Output CSV path. sample_col Name column data containing sample IDs. factors Character vector factor (sample metadata) columns (optional). variables Character vector variable (taxon) columns. NULL, columns sample_col factors treated variables. na_to_zero TRUE, replace NA variable columns 0. indicators Optional data frame variable-level metadata append. Must contain column named indicators_var_col listing variable names; columns indicator fields (becomes one output row). indicators_var_col Name variable-name column indicators.

title: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
text: (invisibly) character matrix written data (without header).

title: Write a PRIMER-ready CSV (samples, variables, factors, optional indicators) — write_primer_csv
text: default, variables NULL, columns sample_col factors treated taxon/variable columns. columns must coercible numeric; otherwise function error move columns factors.

title: primertools 0.2.0
text: Added read_simper() parse PRIMER one-way SIMPER text output files structured within-group -group contribution tables. Added vignette demonstrating read work PRIMER SIMPER outputs.

title: primertools 0.1.1
text: Add aic_permanova() get_permanova_aic() AIC-like comparison PRIMER PERMANOVA models. Add vignette: “Reading PRIMER PERMANOVA outputs”.

title: primertools 0.1.1
text: Added read_permanova_*() helpers parse PRIMER PERMANOVA output.
